Newsom and state of California to reduce population in crowded congregate living spaces to permit social distancing and protect medically vulnerable by releasing/relocating class members who are at high risk of severe illness form COVID-19

Lawyers for California prison inmates filed motion for targeted releases of low-risk inmates who have less than a year left to serve as well as release or relocation of 65+ and those with medical conditions that put them at severe risk from COVID-19
Federal judge grants emergency TRO for two immigrants at the Adelanto Detention Center
Public health experts joined a letter urging Gov. Newsom to release people to address the grave risk of COVID-19 in jails and prisons, focusing on elderly and medically vulnerable

column11: Relevant requests from letter to Governor: Order the Department of Corrections to Lift and Cease Placing Probation and Parole Holds for Violations Where No Immediate and Significant Risk Is Posed to the Community // Precautions Regarding—Including Release of—Medically Fragile and Older Adults​ and Children from Prison and Secure-Care Facilities // Immediate Release of Individuals in Pre-trial Detention Absent Substantial Showing of Imminent Dangerousness to Community // Extend good-time credit: In order to reduce exposure, DOC should issue an emergency 90-days good time credit to allow the release of anyone within 90 days of going hom // Sign clemency applications on your desk // Instruct OJJ to file motions for release of juveniles who pose no imminent and substantial danger to the community

to immediately release (1) people who are being held pretrial who fall into the high-risk categories defined by the CDC, (2) people held for outstanding fines and fees, (3) people arrested for misdemeanor offenses (4) people arrested for a non-violent crime that, under Louisiana statute, would not require a mandatory prison sentence if convicted, and (5) people who are detained on a probation or parole hold, based on an arrest for a non-violent crime for which they would not be mandated to serve a prison sentence if convicted, and who are otherwise in compliance with the terms of their probation or parole.
Still collecting signatures: https://forms.gle/HKPoTHNSakSbBRq4A

column4: Chief Justice Stuart Rabner of NJ Supreme Court
column11: Order to release hundreds of inmates throughout county jails.  This would include people detained for probation violations, municipal court convictions, disorderly person offenses, and for fourth-degree or petty crimes.  The number could be up to 1,000 released to follow stay at home orders and finish sentences after the health emergency is over.

column11: In response to Bergen County Jail, NJ employee testing positive, call for release of all immigrants, especially those vulnerable to infection

column11: Calling for release of those vulnerable to infection and detained for administrative reasons such as violations of conditional discharge, parole, and immigration detainers

Writ of habeas for 116 people vulnerable to infection

Release individuals over 50 or with compromised immune systems/respiratory issues, low-level offenders, those charged with technical violations, those ending their terms of incarceration, noncitizens who are only held on immigration charges. Voluntary surrender dates should be extended so no one is required to report until the crisis has passed. Reduce new arrests, ICE should not arrest solely for immigration.
